Posts.Content: Hi Diamonds,  Thank you so much for your advice and support, I really admire your strength in making your decision. I didn't know there could be a chance of getting leukemia when taking FEC, that's so scary.  My Onc was so blunt - she said "Well, chemotherapy is just poison." and left it at that, I just wanted to get out of there, I couldn't think straight. Because the cancer was oestrogen related, were you advised to have an anti-oestrogen diet?  I've cut out milk, cheese, - all sorts, don't know what to eat any more.  Am seeing a dietitian soon for this, I could share the info if you like. Jane xxx

Posts.Content: Hi M-Bear :) Our cases really do sound similar, I was diagnosed with grade 3 too and ER positive. Will you be taking Tamoxifen at some point?  What you said about oweing it to yourself to give it the best shot and giving it a good whooping, being aggressive back really makes sense to me, thanks, that's really positive :-)   One of the main reasons I'm not sold on chemo is that I haven't told my mum about my situation because she is not in the best of health, and she worries terribly about everything let alone this and I can't explain away a bald head! ;)  She's been through a lot in her life and if I made her ill I just couldn't live with myself.   How did your mum take it? xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, Am so sorry to hear that you're going through such a bad time.  You've been though so much and my heart goes out to you.  I hope you have lots of friends and family around to support you.  I lost an old, good friend at the time of diagnosis/treatment and found this poem helpful.  I hope it helps you in some way, sorry if its a massive cliche.  Sending you love, strength and a huge hug.  Jane xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx Do not stand at my grave and weep I am not there; I do not sleep. I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sun on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn rain. When you awaken in the morning's hush I am the swift uplifting rush Of quiet birds in circled flight. I am the soft stars that shine at night. Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there; I did not die.
Posts.Title: life sucks

Posts.Content: Hi Looby :)  I had a grade 3 tumour 1.5cms removed, then radio, now chemo and after the biopsey the lump felt bigger and sore too, I was worried that the lump was growing but my surgeon told me that it was totally normal as the biopsey needle punctures the lump making the area sore and swell.   I know how you feel, thinking the worst, all the what if's and worse senarios and everything seems worse when you're not sleeping properly.  There are so many excellent treatments available and on this site there have been lots of ladies who've had chemo to shrink the lump before removal.  So hopefully some of those ladies will reply to you.  Sending you love, strength and a huge hug and hope you're reunited with your children soon.  Keep in touch and let us know how you get on.  Jane xxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Posts.Title: chemo in affected arm

Posts.Content: Hi Americagirl, that's brilliant news, so glad for you!  :)   I had exactly the same - entire tumour out with good margins and lymph nodes clear :)  Will you be taking Tamoxifen after radiotherapy?  So, far i've found the op and radiotherapy not half as bad as i thought it would be.  Today's my frist day of chemo - am ok at the moment so fingers crossed it stays that way ;)  it's easy to think the worst with all this business we're all going through, i do it when i'm over tired. Keep positive and congratulations!  Jane xxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Surgery results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Zoe,  I was nervous too about the chemo, out of all of it i was dreading it the most, mainly due to other people's experiences but i've learned that everyone reacts differently to it. Do you know which type of chemo you will be having?  I'm having 6 infusions of  FEC, my oncologist told me this is given to ladies whose cancer hasn't spread to the lymph nodes, so maybe you'll have the same.  I too had my shoulder length hair cut to my chin, then to a short pixie cut which is really easy to manage the reason for this is that there is something called a Cold Cap (don't know if you've heard about it) but bascially its a cap they put on your head before and during chemo and it freezes your hair folicles giving you a 60% chance of keeping your hair!  I had it yesterday and it was pretty cold, yes, but bearable and the nurses keep you really warm with blankets and give you hot tea.  So far, after my chemo yesterday I have no side effects!  Hope it stays like that :)  Am here for you anytime, let me know how you get on :)  Jane xxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Surgery results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Janet :)  I was shaking and breathing hard on my first treatment but they told me to relax and breathe normally and it was ok then. One radiographer said,  'Don't worry it won't hurt, it's not a laser zapping you like on star wars!'  Once I realised the rays don't hurt while youre having the treatment I was ok, afterwards it just felt like i'd been in the sun, keep using the cream all over your effected side including your back, neck, collar bone area etc.  I used simple soap which really helped and drank 2 litres of water a day which helped with the tiredness.  In the end I couldn't believe the last session came about so quickly (had 15 sessions and 5 boosters) and thankfully had no burns.  It's not so bad once you get the first one out of the way. Take care, Jane xxxxxx
